project.teaser: In FoQaCiA, we will expand the theoretical basis for the design of quantum algorithms. Our view is that the future success of quantum computing critically depends on advances at the most fundamental level, and that large-scale investments in quantum implementations will only...
project.objective:
In FoQaCiA, we will expand the theoretical basis for the design of quantum algorithms. Our view is that the future success of quantum computing critically depends on advances at the most fundamental level, and that large-scale investments in quantum implementations will only pay off if they can draw on additional foundational insights and ideas. While several powerful quantum algorithms are known, the basic techniques they employ are few and far between. Largely, it still remains to be discovered how to systematically harness the quantum for computation.
We study four areas of quantum phenomenology: (i) Quantum contextuality, non-classicality, and quantum advantage, (ii) Complexity of classical simulation of quantum computation, (iii) Arithmetic of quantum circuits, and (iv) Efficiency of fault-tolerant quantum computation.
These fields are chosen for two reasons. First, their progress is of great importance for the physical realisation and the broad applicability of quantum computation. Regarding (i), one of the simplest proofs of quantum contextuality, Mermin’s star, has recently been employed to prove (Bravyi, Gosset, König) that bounded-depth quantum circuits are more powerful than their classical analogues. We seek to expand this result beyond bounded depth. In (ii), we study the quantum speedup by shaving off the redundant part – the efficiently classically simulable. In (iii), we aim to provide more efficient techniques for gate and circuit synthesis, utilising the number-theoretic underpinnings of the problem. Regarding (iv), given the celebrated threshold theorem, and the fact that the error threshold is now known to be within reach of experiment, we will tackle the remaining challenge of reducing the cost of fault tolerance.
The second reason for selecting the above work areas is to mine them for foundational quantum mechanical structures and find related quantum algorithmic uses.
project.title: Foundations of quantum computational advantage
project.keywords: Quantum computing, contextuality, non-locality, Wigner functions, classical simulation, fault tolerance, magic state distillation, quantum cryptography,gate synthesis,number theory,topological methods

article.title: New techniques underlying the design of efficient quantum algorithms

result.title: Github release of code for computing with Heisenberg and Clifford groups built on arbitrary abelian groups (T3.1)
result.description: Stable release of open source Julia code for computing representations, cohomology, group algebras and other algebraic invariants of Heisenberg and Clifford groups over algebraic number fields using OSCAR (Open Source Computer Algebra Research system). This will enable exact computations in small dimensions that will further inform our theoretical investigations into the arithmetic structures of their orbits on states, codes, circuits, polytopes, etc. It will also let us study the role played by non-isomorphic maximal orders in questions of exact circuit synthesis in arithmetic groups.

result.title: Report on resource theory of non-classicality for causal structures (T1.1)
result.description: Report on developing a compositional resource theory of non-classicality for arbitrary causal structures. This will extend contextuality analysis and quantification to arbitrary scenarios, including generalisations of the noncontextuality and non-locality constraints on classical ontological models. It will enable a principled extension of contextuality analysis and measures of contextuality to computational settings such as the circuit model and multi-agent communication.

result.title: Equivariant simplicial distributions and quantum contextuality

details.authors: Cihan Okay, Igor Sikora

result.title: Report on representation of quantum algorithms in extended stabilizer formalisms (T2.2)
result.description: Report on the representation of quantum algorithms in extensions of the Pauli stabilizer formalism. The report will discuss (i) algebraic generalizations of the stabilizer formalism based on group theoretic methods for describing quantum algorithms; (ii) the cnc-construction; specifically prospects and limitations, and (iii) the Lambda polytopes; specifically how known hidden-variable descriptions found for certain algorithms carry over to the Lambda polytopes.

result.title: Unbounded Sharing of Nonlocality Using Projective Measurements

details.authors: Souradeep Sasmal, Som Kanjilal, Alok Kumar Pan

result.title: Report on non-continuous equivalence transformations for topological circuits (T4.3)
result.description: Report on discrete equivalence transformation for encoded gate operation. Based on the currently existing graphical form of the transformation rules, their rigorous mathematical description is established, and a corresponding efficient representation as a data structure is identified.

result.title: Combining contextuality and causality: a game semantics approach

details.authors: Samson Abramsky, Rui Soares Barbosa, Amy Searle

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
